elements.content: Reactions of hydrated rare earth nitrates with formamide under mild solvothermal reaction conditions give three different rare earth formate structure types Ln­(HCOO)3, Ln­(HCOO)3·(HCONH2)2, and [CH­(NH2)2]­[Ln­(HCOO)4]. The conditions for the formation of a specific structure type were determined as a function of the size of the rare earth cation, the reaction time, and the reaction temperature. Thirteen previously unreported rare earth formates were obtained; nine were isostructural compounds with the composition Ln­(HCOO)3·(HCONH2)2 (denoted by LnFA, Ln = Y (1Y), Sm (2Sm), Eu (3Eu), Gd (4Gd), Tb (5Tb), Ho (6Ho), Tm (7Tm), Yb (8Yb), and Lu (9Lu)), and four were isostructural compounds with the composition [CH­(NH2)2]­[Ln­(HCOO)4] (denoted by LnFMD, Ln = Sm (10Sm), Ho (11Ho), Tm (12Tm), and Lu (13Lu)). All compounds contain metal ions that are eight coordinated by oxygen atoms and are connected by anti–anti bridging formato ligands to form frameworks. The coordination geometry is bisdisphenoid in LnFA and square antiprismatic in LnFMD. In contrast, the larger rare earth ions that adopt the Ln­(HCOO)3 structure are nine coordinated by oxygen atoms in tricapped trigonal prismatic coordination geometry. The luminescence properties of 2Sm, 3Eu, 5Tb, and 10Sm were investigated by solid state photoluminescence spectroscopy in the range of 300–800 nm. Rare earth oxides were also found to react directly with formamide in the presence of a small amount of water to give the same compositions suggesting that the reaction chemistry can provide a basis for a process to recover rare earth metals from end-of-life products containing oxides such as the phosphors used in fluorescent light bulbs. This possibility was demonstrated by crystallizing rare earth formates starting with a commercially available trichromatic phosphor.

elements.content: Mild solvothermal reactions of rare earth nitrates and oxides with formamide/water result in three rare earth formates, Ln­(HCOO)3, Ln­(HCOO)3·(HCONH2)2, and [CH­(NH2)2]­[Ln­(HCOO)4], depending on metal cation size, reaction time, and temperature. The possibility of using this chemistry for a rare earths recovery process from end-of-life products was demonstrated by crystallizing rare earth formates starting with a commercially available trichromatic phosphor.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are inorganic–organic hybrid materials which contain metal cations connected by coordination with organic bridging ligands to form extended structures. The high porosity and high surface areas of many MOFs have suggested potential applications in selective adsorption and catalysis. The large number of different ligands and metals that can be used to build MOFs permits the introduction of other physical properties such as conductivity, optical behavior, and magnetism, leading to other potential applications. Lanthanide ions are of interest for constructing MOFs, because the high ligand coordination numbers give rise to new structures not found for transition metal ions.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are inorganic-organic hybrid materials which contain metal cations connected by coordination with organic bridging ligands to form extended structures. The high porosity and high surface areas of many MOFs have suggested potential applications in selective adsorption and catalysis. The large number of different ligands and metals that can be used to build MOFs permits the introduction of other physical properties such as conductivity, optical behavior, and magnetism, leading to other potential applications. Lanthanide ions are of interest for constructing MOFs, because the high ligand coordination numbers give rise to new structures not found for transition metal ions.

elements.content: The rare earth elements–15 lanthanides (Ln) and scandium and yttriumare important components in materials used in sustainable energy and high technology applications. Magnets in wind turbines, batteries in hybrid automobiles, and fluid cracking catalysts are examples. High technology applications such as energy efficient lighting, consumer electronics, and high temperature superconductor devices also depend on rare earth containing materials.

elements.content: The optical and magnetic properties of lanthanide based metal organic frameworks (Ln-MOFs) have been investigated. The bridging ligands of choice for the synthesis of Ln-MOFs have often been carboxylate ligands, because Ln ions have a high binding preference for hard donors such as oxygen atoms. Thus, carboxylate ligands such as oxalate, formate, pyridinecarboxylate, and benzenecarboxylate have been used.

Thus, carboxylate ligands such as oxalate, formate, pyridinecarboxylate, and benzenecarboxylate have been used.

elements.content: Hydrated transition metal and rare earth formate compounds were studied several decades ago because of interest in their physical properties. Several rare earth metal compounds containing formate with other ligands have been described, but here we consider frameworks with formate as the only bridging ligand. Anhydrous and hydrated rare earth formates with the composition Ln­(HCOO)3·xH2O (where x = 0–2 and Ln = La–Lu, Y) are structurally well characterized. Ln­(HCOO)3·(HCONH2)2 is a second example with a neutral Ln­(HCOO)3 framework and two formamide molecules as co-ligands. Only two members of this structure type containing Dy and Er have been previously reported. Compounds with the general formula [AH+]­[Ln­(HCOO)4 –] (where AH+ = ammonium or organic cation) form a third group. Examples with NH2CHNH2 + as the organic cation were obtained recently for Y, Eu, Gd, Tb, Er, Dy, and Yb, but to our knowledge the other four members of this family are not known.

Anhydrous and hydrated rare earth formates with the composition Ln(HCOO)3⋅xH2O (where x = 0-2 and Ln = La-Lu, Y) are structurally well characterized. Ln(HCOO)3⋅(HCONH2)2 is a second example with a neutral Ln(HCOO)3 framework and two formamide molecules as co-ligands. Only two members of this structure type containing Dy and Er have been previously reported. Compounds with the general formula [AH+][Ln(HCOO)4 -] (where AH+ = ammonium or organic cation) form a third group. Examples with NH2CHNH2 + as the organic cation were obtained recently for Y, Eu, Gd, Tb, Er, Dy, and Yb, but to our knowledge the other four members of this family are not known.

elements.content: In the present work, we have systematically investigated conditions for the synthesis of the different rare earth metal formate frameworks by reaction of hydrated rare earth nitrates and formamide under mild solvothermal conditions. The specific compound formed was shown to depend on the size of the rare earth cation and on the reaction time and temperature. We have previously used this approach for the synthesis of transition metal formates [M­(HCOO)2(HCONH2)2] (M = Mn, Ni, Cu, Zn, and Mg).
elements.clean_text: In the present work, we have systematically investigated conditions for the synthesis of the different rare earth metal formate frameworks by reaction of hydrated rare earth nitrates and formamide under mild solvothermal conditions. The specific compound formed was shown to depend on the size of the rare earth cation and on the reaction time and temperature. We have previously used this approach for the synthesis of transition metal formates [M(HCOO)2(HCONH2)2] (M = Mn, Ni, Cu, Zn, and Mg).

Nine are isostructural Ln­(HCOO)3·(HCONH2)2 compounds, denoted by LnFA, Ln = Y (1Y), Sm (2Sm), Eu (3Eu), Gd (4Gd), Tb (5Tb), Ho (6Ho), Tm (7Tm), Yb (8Yb), and Lu (9Lu)), and four are isostructural [NH2CHNH2]­[Ln­(HCOO)4] compounds denoted by LnFMD, Ln = Sm (10Sm), Ho (11Ho), Tm (12Tm)­and Lu (13Lu). Syntheses, room temperature crystal structures, and thermal properties of the new compounds together with the luminescence properties of 2Sm, 3Eu, 5Tb, and 10Sm are described.

elements.content:
All starting materials were reagent grade, commercially available (Sigma-Aldrich, St. Louis, MO, U.S.), and were used without further purification.

Synthesis of Ln­(HCOO)<sub>3</sub>·(HCONH<sub>2</sub>)<sub>2</sub> (Ln = <bold>1Y</bold>, <bold>2Sm</bold>, <bold>3Eu</bold>, <bold>4Gd</bold>, <bold>5Tb</bold>, <bold>6Ho</bold>, <bold>7Tm</bold>, <bold>8Yb</bold>, and <bold>9Lu</bold>)

Compounds 1Y–9Lu were synthesized by using the same general solvothermal synthesis procedure. The reaction conditions were varied, however, in order to determine the conditions where the LnFA phases could be obtained in pure form and are summarized in Figure . The general procedure for the syntheses of compounds 1Y–9Lu is as follows: 0.5 mmol of hydrated rare earth­(III) nitrate was transferred to a 22 mL glass vial and mixed with 5 mL of formamide. All of the nitrates completely dissolved in the formamide to give clear solutions. Vials were sealed and heated at different temperatures (50–70 °C) for different times (72–120 h), followed by cooling to room temperature in ambient atmosphere. The final products consist of rhombohedral shaped crystals. The products were filtered, washed with ethanol, and dried in a vacuum oven (see the (section S1) for details).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials

All starting materials were reagent grade, commercially available (Sigma-Aldrich, St. Louis, MO, U.S.), and were used without further purification.

Synthesis of Ln(HCOO)3⋅(HCONH2)2 (Ln = 1Y, 2Sm, 3Eu, 4Gd, 5Tb, 6Ho, 7Tm, 8Yb, and 9Lu)

Compounds 1Y-9Lu were synthesized by using the same general solvothermal synthesis procedure. The reaction conditions were varied, however, in order to determine the conditions where the LnFA phases could be obtained in pure form and are summarized in Figure . The general procedure for the syntheses of compounds 1Y-9Lu is as follows: 0.5 mmol of hydrated rare earth(III) nitrate was transferred to a 22 mL glass vial and mixed with 5 mL of formamide. All of the nitrates completely dissolved in the formamide to give clear solutions. Vials were sealed and heated at different temperatures (50-70 °C) for different times (72-120 h), followed by cooling to room temperature in ambient atmosphere. The final products consist of rhombohedral shaped crystals. The products were filtered, washed with ethanol, and dried in a vacuum oven (see the  (section S1) for details).

elements.content: Phases obtained from the reactions of formamide and hydrated rare earth nitrates at different reaction temperatures and times.
elements.clean_text: 1  Phases obtained from the reactions of formamide and hydrated rare earth nitrates at different reaction temperatures and times.

elements.content: The optimum reaction temperatures and times to obtain pure 2Sm were 70 °C and 120 h; to prepare 1Y, 3Eu, 4Gd, 5Tb, and 6Ho were 70 °C and 72 h; and to obtain pure 7Tm, 8Yb, and 9Lu were 50 °C and 120 h. At temperatures higher than 50 °C, the smaller lanthanide cations (Tm, Yb, and Lu) formed mixtures of the respective LnFA and LnFMD phases. To obtain pure phases of these compounds, the reaction temperature was decreased and the reaction time increased (see Figure ).
elements.clean_text: The optimum reaction temperatures and times to obtain pure 2Sm were 70 °C and 120 h; to prepare 1Y, 3Eu, 4Gd, 5Tb, and 6Ho were 70 °C and 72 h; and to obtain pure 7Tm, 8Yb, and 9Lu were 50 °C and 120 h. At temperatures higher than 50 °C, the smaller lanthanide cations (Tm, Yb, and Lu) formed mixtures of the respective LnFA and LnFMD phases. To obtain pure phases of these compounds, the reaction temperature was decreased and the reaction time increased (see Figure ).

elements.content: Compounds 10Sm–13Lu were synthesized by using a similar solvothermal synthesis procedure at 100 °C. However, the compounds with small rare earth ions, 12Tm, and 13Lu, crystallized even at 70 °C. A 0.5 mmol amount of hydrated rare earth­(III) nitrate was transferred to a 22 mL glass vial and mixed with 5 mL of formamide. Vials were sealed and heated at 100 °C for 72 h, followed by cooling to room temperature in ambient atmosphere. The final products were prismatic rod shaped crystals. The products were filtered, washed with ethanol, and dried in a vacuum oven. We noted also that reaction at 70 °C for longer reaction periods (>7 days) resulted in the transformation of Ln­(HCOO)3·(HCONH2)2 crystals to [CH­(NH2)2]­[Ln­(HCOO)4] crystals.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [CH(NH2)2][Ln(HCOO)4] (Ln = 10Sm, 11Ho, 12Tm, and 13Lu)

Compounds 10Sm-13Lu were synthesized by using a similar solvothermal synthesis procedure at 100 °C. However, the compounds with small rare earth ions, 12Tm, and 13Lu, crystallized even at 70 °C. A 0.5 mmol amount of hydrated rare earth(III) nitrate was transferred to a 22 mL glass vial and mixed with 5 mL of formamide. Vials were sealed and heated at 100 °C for 72 h, followed by cooling to room temperature in ambient atmosphere. The final products were prismatic rod shaped crystals. The products were filtered, washed with ethanol, and dried in a vacuum oven. We noted also that reaction at 70 °C for longer reaction periods (>7 days) resulted in the transformation of Ln(HCOO)3⋅(HCONH2)2 crystals to [CH(NH2)2][Ln(HCOO)4] crystals.

elements.content: We have also determined the reaction conditions to synthesize the previously reported Ln­(HCOO)3·(HCONH2)2 (Ln = Dy and Er) and [CH­(NH2)2]­[Ln­(HCOO)4] (Ln = Y, Eu, Gd, Tb, Dy, Er, and Yb) compounds and the Ln­(HCOO)3 phases.
elements.clean_text: We have also determined the reaction conditions to synthesize the previously reported Ln(HCOO)3⋅(HCONH2)2 (Ln = Dy and Er) and [CH(NH2)2][Ln(HCOO)4] (Ln = Y, Eu, Gd, Tb, Dy, Er, and Yb) compounds and the Ln(HCOO)3 phases.

elements.content: A similar procedure was used to synthesize 1Y–9Lu (except for 2Sm and 5Tb) starting with rare earth oxides, Ln2O3. The final product of the reaction with Sm2O3 was Sm­(HCOO)3; CeO2 and Tb4O7 did not react with formamide under any of the reaction conditions used.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of 1Y-13Lu Starting with Rare Earth(III) Oxides

A similar procedure was used to synthesize 1Y-9Lu (except for 2Sm and 5Tb) starting with rare earth oxides, Ln2O3. The final product of the reaction with Sm2O3 was Sm(HCOO)3; CeO2 and Tb4O7 did not react with formamide under any of the reaction conditions used.

elements.content: The rare earth­(III) oxide (0.125 mmol) was mixed with 10 mL of formamide and 0.25 mL of water in a 22 mL glass vial. Vials were sealed and heated at 70 °C. LnFA crystals were obtained in yields of 60–80% in 72–120 h reactions. Addition of small amounts of water to the reaction mixtures was found to substantially increase the reaction rate. Too much water, however, results in dissolution of the products. An optimum ratio of 0.25 mL of H2O to 10 mL of formamide was found to be sufficient to generate formate ions by hydrolysis and maximize the product yield.

LnFA crystals were obtained in yields of 60-80% in 72-120 h reactions. Addition of small amounts of water to the reaction mixtures was found to substantially increase the reaction rate. Too much water, however, results in dissolution of the products. An optimum ratio of 0.25 mL of H2O to 10 mL of formamide was found to be sufficient to generate formate ions by hydrolysis and maximize the product yield.

elements.content: Pure phases of 11Ho, 12Tm, and 13Lu (except for 10Sm) were synthesized starting with rare earth oxides following a similar procedure: 0.125 mmol of rare earth­(III) oxide was transferred to a 22 mL glass vial and mixed with 10 mL of formamide and 0.25 mL of H2O. Vials were sealed and heated under autogenous pressure at 100 °C for 72 h. Vials were cooled to room temperature at ambient atmosphere, and the products were filtered, washed with ethanol, and dried in a vacuum oven.

Vials were sealed and heated under autogenous pressure at 100 °C for 72 h. Vials were cooled to room temperature at ambient atmosphere, and the products were filtered, washed with ethanol, and dried in a vacuum oven.

elements.content: The reaction of rare earth oxides with formamide in the presence of a small amount of water suggests that the reaction chemistry can provide a basis for a process to recover rare earth metals from end-of-life products containing oxides such as the phosphors in fluorescent light bulbs. To investigate this possibility, a premixed trichromatic phosphor available from Sigma-Aldrich was used as a model system of a more complex starting rare earth material. The trichromatic phosphor is a mixture of three oxides doped with rare earth metals to form three phosphors: Y2O3:Eu (red), CeMgAl11O19:Tb (green), and BaMgAl10O17:Eu (blue). The mixture is a white powder and was used in the experiments as received.
elements.clean_text:
Reaction of Premixed Phosphor with Formamide (Model System for Rare Earth Recovery)

The reaction of rare earth oxides with formamide in the presence of a small amount of water suggests that the reaction chemistry can provide a basis for a process to recover rare earth metals from end-of-life products containing oxides such as the phosphors in fluorescent light bulbs. To investigate this possibility, a premixed trichromatic phosphor available from Sigma-Aldrich was used as a model system of a more complex starting rare earth material. The trichromatic phosphor is a mixture of three oxides doped with rare earth metals to form three phosphors: Y2O3:Eu (red), CeMgAl11O19:Tb (green), and BaMgAl10O17:Eu (blue). The mixture is a white powder and was used in the experiments as received.

elements.content: The reaction conditions used for these experiments were the same as those used for the reactions of rare earth metal oxides with formamide. In a typical experiment, 0.25 g of premixed phosphor was transferred to a 22 mL glass vial and mixed with 10 mL of formamide and 0.25 mL of water. Vials were sealed, transferred to ovens, and heated to 100 °C. Crystals started to appear in ∼2 h. The solid products were filtered after ∼4 h and dried under vacuum. Under the optical microscope two phases were observed: 2–4 mm size colorless crystals and a microcrystalline powder. The phases were separated by density using a mixture of diiodomethane/acetone. The separated crystals were washed with ethanol and dried under vacuum. The crystals were confirmed to be [CH­(NH2)2]­[Ln­(HCOO)4] from the powder and single crystal X-ray diffraction measurements. The yield was ∼60% based on the starting material weight. The relatively fast product formation results from the small particle size (≤10 μm) of the starting material. Powder diffraction data of the remaining microcrystalline phase indicated that it consisted of the non-rare-earth constituents of the starting material and some other unidentified phases.
elements.clean_text: The reaction conditions used for these experiments were the same as those used for the reactions of rare earth metal oxides with formamide. In a typical experiment, 0.25 g of premixed phosphor was transferred to a 22 mL glass vial and mixed with 10 mL of formamide and 0.25 mL of water. Vials were sealed, transferred to ovens, and heated to 100 °C. Crystals started to appear in ~2 h. The solid products were filtered after ~4 h and dried under vacuum. Under the optical microscope two phases were observed: 2-4 mm size colorless crystals and a microcrystalline powder. The phases were separated by density using a mixture of diiodomethane/acetone. The separated crystals were washed with ethanol and dried under vacuum. The crystals were confirmed to be [CH(NH2)2][Ln(HCOO)4] from the powder and single crystal X-ray diffraction measurements. The yield was ~60% based on the starting material weight. The relatively fast product formation results from the small particle size (≤10 μm) of the starting material. Powder diffraction data of the remaining microcrystalline phase indicated that it consisted of the non-rare-earth constituents of the starting material and some other unidentified phases.

elements.content: Single crystal data were collected using a Siemens SMART platform diffractometer equipped with an Apex-II area detector and using monochromatic Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). A single crystal of suitable size was selected for each phase, coated with paraffin oil to prevent deterioration in humid air, and mounted on a glass fiber using silicone glue. Data sets were collected at 298 K for all of the compounds. Data collection, cell refinement, and data integration were performed by using the APEX2 system. The structures were solved by direct methods using the SHELXS97 program and refined using SHELXL97 incorporated in the WinGX package. The hydrogen atoms of the formate ions and formamides were located in the Fourier maps and refined with riding isotropic thermal parameters. Crystal data are summarized in Table . Selected bond distances and angles are given in Tables S1 and S2.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure Determination

Single crystal data were collected using a Siemens SMART platform diffractometer equipped with an Apex-II area detector and using monochromatic Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). A single crystal of suitable size was selected for each phase, coated with paraffin oil to prevent deterioration in humid air, and mounted on a glass fiber using silicone glue. Data sets were collected at 298 K for all of the compounds. Data collection, cell refinement, and data integration were performed by using the APEX2 system. The structures were solved by direct methods using the SHELXS97 program and refined using SHELXL97 incorporated in the WinGX package. The hydrogen atoms of the formate ions and formamides were located in the Fourier maps and refined with riding isotropic thermal parameters. Crystal data are summarized in Table . Selected bond distances and angles are given in  Tables S1 and S2.

elements.content: Infrared spectra of the samples were measured with a Galaxy series FTIR 5000 spectrometer using KBr pellets in the range of 400–4000 cm–1 at ambient conditions. Elemental analyses were performed by Galbraith Laboratories (Knoxville, TN, USA). Thermogravimetric analyses were performed using a Hi-Res TGA 2950 thermogravimetric system. Samples were heated in air to 973 K/1073 K with a heating rate at 1 °C min–1. The samples were imaged and analyzed by a JEOL JSM6330 field emission scanning electron microscope (SEM; acceleration voltage, 15 kV) equipped with an energy-dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDX). Fluorescence measurements were performed using a PTI QuantaMaster QM4 CW spectrofluorometer.
elements.clean_text:
Characterization

Infrared spectra of the samples were measured with a Galaxy series FTIR 5000 spectrometer using KBr pellets in the range of 400-4000 cm-1 at ambient conditions. Elemental analyses were performed by Galbraith Laboratories (Knoxville, TN, USA). Thermogravimetric analyses were performed using a Hi-Res TGA 2950 thermogravimetric system. Samples were heated in air to 973 K/1073 K with a heating rate at 1 °C min-1. The samples were imaged and analyzed by a JEOL JSM6330 field emission scanning electron microscope (SEM; acceleration voltage, 15 kV) equipped with an energy-dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDX). Fluorescence measurements were performed using a PTI QuantaMaster QM4 CW spectrofluorometer.

elements.content: All compounds were first synthesized by reaction of the hydrated rare earth­(III) nitrates with formamide under mild solvothermal conditions at 50–100 °C. Three different product series were obtained from the reactions depending on the reaction temperature, time, and size of the rare earth cation (Figure ). At all the reaction conditions used (50, 70, and 100 °C and for 3, 5, or 7 days), the larger rare earth cations (Ln = La, Ce, Pr, and Nd) form Ln­(HCOO)3 as the final product. No other compounds were observed under all experimental conditions. Comparisons of powder X-ray diffraction patterns with the reported data were used to confirm phase purity. In contrast, the medium and small sized rare earth cations (Gd–Yb, Y, and Lu) did not yield Ln­(HCOO)3 as the final product, but formed either LnFA or LnFMD phases depending on the reaction conditions. Samarium is intermediate, and consequently obtaining pure SmFA or SmFMD phases is difficult because of the tendency to form Sm­(HCOO)3 as an impurity phase together with SmFA or SmFMD. Eu formed Eu­(HCOO)3 at low temperatures (∼50 °C) and long reaction times (∼7 days). The differences are related to the effect of the ionic radius of the lanthanide ion on its preferred coordination. Both LnFA and LnFMD have three-dimensional framework structures with a single type of a rhombohedral cavity. In the LnFA structure, the cavity of the Ln­(HCOO)3 framework is occupied by two formamide ligands coordinated to the rare earth cation; in LnFMD the cavity of the [Ln­(HCOO)4]− framework is occupied by the [CH­(NH2)2]+ cation. In both structures, the rare earth ion is eight coordinated by oxygen atoms. In contrast, in the Ln­(HCOO)3 structure adopted by the larger rare earth ions, the rare earth ions are nine coordinated by oxygen atoms. Samarium and europium are intermediate in size and form all three structure types. Of the nine LnFA structures, 2Sm is the only compound that contains disordered terminating formamide molecules, consistent with its large ion size that results in a framework cavity too large for a well ordered arrangement. The difference in stabilities of LnFA or LnFMD phases is also influenced by ionic size. To obtain pure LnFA compounds with the smaller rare earths, Tm, Yb, and Lu, it was necessary to lower the reaction temperature to 50 °C.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis

All compounds were first synthesized by reaction of the hydrated rare earth(III) nitrates with formamide under mild solvothermal conditions at 50-100 °C. Three different product series were obtained from the reactions depending on the reaction temperature, time, and size of the rare earth cation (Figure ). At all the reaction conditions used (50, 70, and 100 °C and for 3, 5, or 7 days), the larger rare earth cations (Ln = La, Ce, Pr, and Nd) form Ln(HCOO)3 as the final product. No other compounds were observed under all experimental conditions. Comparisons of powder X-ray diffraction patterns with the reported data were used to confirm phase purity. In contrast, the medium and small sized rare earth cations (Gd-Yb, Y, and Lu) did not yield Ln(HCOO)3 as the final product, but formed either LnFA or LnFMD phases depending on the reaction conditions. Samarium is intermediate, and consequently obtaining pure SmFA or SmFMD phases is difficult because of the tendency to form Sm(HCOO)3 as an impurity phase together with SmFA or SmFMD. Eu formed Eu(HCOO)3 at low temperatures (~50 °C) and long reaction times (~7 days). The differences are related to the effect of the ionic radius of the lanthanide ion on its preferred coordination. Both LnFA and LnFMD have three-dimensional framework structures with a single type of a rhombohedral cavity. In the LnFA structure, the cavity of the Ln(HCOO)3 framework is occupied by two formamide ligands coordinated to the rare earth cation; in LnFMD the cavity of the [Ln(HCOO)4]- framework is occupied by the [CH(NH2)2]+ cation. In both structures, the rare earth ion is eight coordinated by oxygen atoms. In contrast, in the Ln(HCOO)3 structure adopted by the larger rare earth ions, the rare earth ions are nine coordinated by oxygen atoms. Samarium and europium are intermediate in size and form all three structure types. Of the nine LnFA structures, 2Sm is the only compound that contains disordered terminating formamide molecules, consistent with its large ion size that results in a framework cavity too large for a well ordered arrangement. The difference in stabilities of LnFA or LnFMD phases is also influenced by ionic size. To obtain pure LnFA compounds with the smaller rare earths, Tm, Yb, and Lu, it was necessary to lower the reaction temperature to 50 °C.

elements.content: Formamide plays an important role. In the reactions of formamide with hydrated nitrates, the formate ions are formed by hydrolysis of formamide by the water of hydration. The reaction kinetics and the mechanism of this hydrolysis have been widely investigated both experimentally and theoretically and several mechanisms have been proposed. Thus, at elevated temperatures and pressures with the presence of a small amount of water in the reaction mixture, the hydrolysis mechanism for formamide can be depicted as in Scheme .

The reaction kinetics and the mechanism of this hydrolysis have been widely investigated both experimentally and theoretically and several mechanisms have been proposed. Thus, at elevated temperatures and pressures with the presence of a small amount of water in the reaction mixture, the hydrolysis mechanism for formamide can be depicted as in Scheme .

<fig fig-type="scheme" id="sch1" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label>1</label>
<graphic id="gr1" orientation="portrait" position="float" xlink:href="cg-2014-01421u_0009.tif"></graphic>
</fig>

In the first series of compounds, Ln­(HCOO)3·(HCONH2)2, formate ions formed in situ bridge the metal centers and the formamide molecules are terminating ligands. This phase is formed at lower reaction temperatures (50–70 °C). At higher temperatures (∼100 °C), formamide is converted to formamidine, and the [CH­(NH2)2]­[Ln­(HCOO)4] phases are formed. The formamidinium cation formed in situ neutralizes the charge of the anionic metal formate framework. The mechanism for the formation of formamidine from formamide under solvothermal conditions is not well understood, but two possible mechanisms can be suggested. A mechanism which assumes the presence of excess formamide is illustrated in Scheme .

This phase is formed at lower reaction temperatures (50-70 °C). At higher temperatures (~100 °C), formamide is converted to formamidine, and the [CH(NH2)2][Ln(HCOO)4] phases are formed. The formamidinium cation formed in situ neutralizes the charge of the anionic metal formate framework. The mechanism for the formation of formamidine from formamide under solvothermal conditions is not well understood, but two possible mechanisms can be suggested. A mechanism which assumes the presence of excess formamide is illustrated in Scheme .

In order to demonstrate the potential of reactions with formamide as a route for the recovery of rare earths from end-of-life products, reactions of formamide with rare earth oxides and a commercially available premixed trichromatic phosphor were investigated. Repeating the experiments described for the nitrates gave the same final results. The reaction times, however, had to be increased to 12 days or more to obtain significant crystallization of the rare earth formate frameworks. Some formamide hydrolysis is needed to generate the formate ligands. Possible pathways could involve slow formamide decomposition to form hydrogen cyanide and water or the presence of adventitious water. Deliberate addition of water increases the hydrolysis of formamide and significantly increases the reaction rate; thus the reaction time was reduced from 12 to 3–5 days. The amount of water added to the reaction mixture must be controlled to prevent dissolution of the products and to avoid the crystallization of ammonium formate as a byproduct.

The reaction times, however, had to be increased to 12 days or more to obtain significant crystallization of the rare earth formate frameworks. Some formamide hydrolysis is needed to generate the formate ligands. Possible pathways could involve slow formamide decomposition to form hydrogen cyanide and water or the presence of adventitious water. Deliberate addition of water increases the hydrolysis of formamide and significantly increases the reaction rate; thus the reaction time was reduced from 12 to 3-5 days. The amount of water added to the reaction mixture must be controlled to prevent dissolution of the products and to avoid the crystallization of ammonium formate as a byproduct.

elements.content: The structures of all of the compounds were determined using single crystal X-ray diffraction at room temperature. The formulas are further confirmed by the elemental analyses, and the phase purities were confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction ( Figures S1 and S2).
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structures

The structures of all of the compounds were determined using single crystal X-ray diffraction at room temperature. The formulas are further confirmed by the elemental analyses, and the phase purities were confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction ( Figures S1 and S2).

elements.content: The crystal structures of the LnFA and LnFMD corresponding to other rare earth ions have been reported. The structures of two examples of the newly synthesized compounds are briefly described for comparison with the literature data. The details can be found in the CIF files in the .
elements.clean_text: The crystal structures of the LnFA and LnFMD corresponding to other rare earth ions have been reported. The structures of two examples of the newly synthesized compounds are briefly described for comparison with the literature data. The details can be found in the CIF files in the .

elements.content: All of the LnFA compounds are isostructural and crystallize in the monoclinic space group C2 with small differences in lattice parameters. The LnFMD compounds are isostructural and crystallize in the orthorhombic chiral space group C2221. As illustrated in Figures and , both structures consist of one crystallographically independent Ln3+ ion, coordinated by eight oxygen atoms and bridged by the end-to-end connecting anti–anti type formate ligands. The geometry of the coordination polyhedron can be considered to be a distorted bisdisphenoid in LnFA and square antiprism in LnFMD. The LnFA structure has a three-dimensional ReO3-like framework with a single type of a rhombohedral shaped cavity (Figure ), and the LnFMD structure has a three-dimensional framework with rhombohedral shaped channels along the a direction (Figure ). In the LnFA structure, the cavity of the neutral Ln­(HCOO)3 framework is occupied by two terminating formamide ligands coordinated to the Ln3+ cation; in LnFMD the negatively charged cavity of the [Ln­(HCOO)4]− framework is occupied by the [CH­(NH2)2]+ cations.

The geometry of the coordination polyhedron can be considered to be a distorted bisdisphenoid in LnFA and square antiprism in LnFMD. The LnFA structure has a three-dimensional ReO3-like framework with a single type of a rhombohedral shaped cavity (Figure ), and the LnFMD structure has a three-dimensional framework with rhombohedral shaped channels along the a direction (Figure ). elements.content: The fluorescence spectra of 2Sm, 10Sm, 3Eu, and 5Tb were measured in the solid state at room temperature. Well ground polycrystalline samples of each compound were used for the measurements. The excitation and emission spectra of Sm and Tb compounds are typical for these ions and are described in the (sections S2 and S3 and Figures S3 and S4). The data for Eu show an unusual feature and are described in following text.
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescence Properties

The fluorescence spectra of 2Sm, 10Sm, 3Eu, and 5Tb were measured in the solid state at room temperature. Well ground polycrystalline samples of each compound were used for the measurements. The excitation and emission spectra of Sm and Tb compounds are typical for these ions and are described in the  (sections S2 and S3 and Figures S3 and S4). The data for Eu show an unusual feature and are described in following text.

elements.content: The photoluminescence spectra for 3Eu are shown in Figure . The emission spectrum was obtained by exciting the samples at 394 nm which corresponds to the 7F0 → 5L6 transition of Eu3+ ions, and the excitation spectrum was obtained by monitoring the emission of the 5D0 → 7F2 transition at 610 nm. The strong, well defined peaks in the spectrum are typical for compounds containing trivalent Eu ions.

The strong, well defined peaks in the spectrum are typical for compounds containing trivalent Eu ions.

elements.content: The emission spectrum of 3Eu with all of the assigned transitions is shown in Figure a. All of the emission peaks observed in the spectrum can be assigned satisfactorily to transitions from the excited state 5D0 to multiple ground state levels of 7F J (J = 1–4) of Eu3+. By comparing the peak positions with those reported in the literature, the emission peaks at 589, 614, 648, and 697 nm can be assigned to 5D0 → 7F1, 5D0 → 7F2, 5D0 → 7F3, and 5D0 → 7F4 transitions, respectively. No peak corresponding to the 5D0 → 7F0 transition was observed.

All of the emission peaks observed in the spectrum can be assigned satisfactorily to transitions from the excited state 5D0 to multiple ground state levels of 7F J  (J = 1-4) of Eu3+. By comparing the peak positions with those reported in the literature, the emission peaks at 589, 614, 648, and 697 nm can be assigned to 5D0 → 7F1, 5D0 → 7F2, 5D0 → 7F3, and 5D0 → 7F4 transitions, respectively. No peak corresponding to the 5D0 → 7F0 transition was observed.

elements.content: The observed intensities for the 7F1, 7F2, and 7F4 transitions are similar, a result not normally observed for Eu3+ occupying a low symmetry site. The Eu3+ spectrum has both transitions which are hypersensitive to the symmetry environment of Eu3+ ions and transitions which are insensitive to the local symmetry. Normally, in noncentrosymmetric systems where Eu3+ occupies a site without inversion symmetry, the hypersensitive transition 5D0 → 7F2 is expected to be more intense than the insensitive magnetic-dipole transition 5D0 → 7F1. The ratio of the intensities of these two transitions is a sensitive parameter of the Eu environment. Since the transitions observed in 3Eu showed different widths, the ratio of the integrated intensities of the 5D0 → 7F2 to 5D0 → 7F1 transitions was calculated to determine the asymmetry of the environment of Eu3+. The calculated value of 1.75 suggests that the Eu3+ ion is located at an asymmetric site, yet the small asymmetric ratio suggests that the Eu3+ site is only slightly distorted. A difference in the spectroscopic site symmetry of Eu3+ relative to the crystallographic site symmetry is a possible explanation. Such observations are uncommon, but previous reports include the studies of Na9[EuW10O36]·14H2O (Sá Ferreira et al.) and of YPO4:Eu3+ (Parchur and Ningthoujam)

elements.content: A comparison of the IR spectra of 2Sm and 10Sm is shown in Figure S5. The IR spectra of the nine LnFA compounds are very similar to slight frequency variations and show the characteristic bands for the HCONH2 and the HCOO groups. In all compounds, the main absorption bands were observed in the regions of N–H stretching (3100–3500 cm–1), N–H bending (1680–1700 cm–1), asymmetric O–C–O stretching (1580–1600 cm–1), asymmetric O–C–O deformation (1370–1400 cm–1), and symmetric O–C–O stretching and N–H stretching (1320–1360 cm–1). The IR spectra of 10Sm–13Lu are similar as expected, and most of the characteristic IR bands of LnFMD compounds appear in the same frequency regions as those for the LnFA compounds ( Figure S6) because of the similar bonding environments of bridging formate ligands and the similarities of stretching and vibration modes of HCOO, HCONH2, and CH­(NH2)2 groups.
elements.clean_text:
Infrared Spectra

A comparison of the IR spectra of 2Sm and 10Sm is shown in  Figure S5. The IR spectra of the nine LnFA compounds are very similar to slight frequency variations and show the characteristic bands for the HCONH2  and the HCOO groups. In all compounds, the main absorption bands were observed in the regions of N-H stretching (3100-3500 cm-1), N-H bending (1680-1700 cm-1), asymmetric O-C-O stretching (1580-1600 cm-1), asymmetric O-C-O deformation (1370-1400 cm-1), and symmetric O-C-O stretching and N-H stretching (1320-1360 cm-1). The IR spectra of 10Sm-13Lu are similar as expected, and most of the characteristic IR bands of LnFMD compounds appear in the same frequency regions as those for the LnFA compounds ( Figure S6) because of the similar bonding environments of bridging formate ligands and the similarities of stretching and vibration modes of HCOO, HCONH2, and CH(NH2)2 groups.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) of LnFA and LnFMD compounds were performed in air to assess thermal stabilities. All of the compounds were isothermally equilibrated at 323 K followed by heating to 973 K/1073 K. No weight loss was observed below ∼400 K for any of the compounds confirming the absence of guest molecules.
elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric Analyses

Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) of LnFA and LnFMD compounds were performed in air to assess thermal stabilities. All of the compounds were isothermally equilibrated at 323 K followed by heating to 973 K/1073 K. No weight loss was observed below ~400 K for any of the compounds confirming the absence of guest molecules.

elements.content: Three weight losses were observed for LnFA (1Y, 2Sm, 3Eu, 4Gd, 5Tb, 6Ho, 7Tm, 8Yb, and 9Lu). The results for ground samples (vide infra) are summarized in Table and in Figure S6. The data for 2Sm are shown in Figure as an example. The samarium compound loses weight (23.16%) below ∼400 K. The powder X-ray diffraction pattern of the residue after the first weight loss shows the formation of Sm­(HCOO)3, indicating loss of the coordinated formamide molecules. The weight loss corresponds to the loss of two molecules of formamide (24.10%). The anhydrous metal formate then decomposes at ∼614 K; an additional small weight loss occurs in the temperature range of 773–823 K. Previous studies of thermal decomposition of anhydrous rare earth formates have shown that decomposition leads to the (partial) formation of rare earth oxycarbonates Ln2O2·CO3 which then decompose at higher temperature. The calculated weight loss for the decomposition of Sm­(HCOO)3 completely to Sm2O 3 is 29.72%, in agreement with the observed total weight loss of 29.18% for the final two decomposition steps.
elements.clean_text:
LnFA

Three weight losses were observed for LnFA (1Y, 2Sm, 3Eu, 4Gd, 5Tb, 6Ho, 7Tm, 8Yb, and 9Lu). The results for ground samples (vide infra) are summarized in Table  and in  Figure S6. The data for 2Sm are shown in Figure  as an example. The samarium compound loses weight (23.16%) below ~400 K. The powder X-ray diffraction pattern of the residue after the first weight loss shows the formation of Sm(HCOO)3, indicating loss of the coordinated formamide molecules. The weight loss corresponds to the loss of two molecules of formamide (24.10%). The anhydrous metal formate then decomposes at ~614 K; an additional small weight loss occurs in the temperature range of 773-823 K. Previous studies of thermal decomposition of anhydrous rare earth formates have shown that decomposition leads to the (partial) formation of rare earth oxycarbonates Ln2O2⋅CO3 which then decompose at higher temperature. The calculated weight loss for the decomposition of Sm(HCOO)3 completely to Sm2O 3 is 29.72%, in agreement with the observed total weight loss of 29.18% for the final two decomposition steps.

All of the LnFA compounds in finely ground form (average particle size < 80 μm estimated from optical microscopy) decompose similarly to 2Sm ( Figure S6) with initial weight losses in the temperature region of 498–548 K (Table ). The slight differences (∼1%) between the theoretical and observed values for the first decomposition step could be a result of a small number of formamide vacancies formed during either the synthesis or drying process. The observed weight losses for the second and third steps are in good agreement with the calculated values.
elements.clean_text: All of the LnFA compounds in finely ground form (average particle size < 80 μm estimated from optical microscopy) decompose similarly to 2Sm ( Figure S6) with initial weight losses in the temperature region of 498-548 K (Table ). The slight differences (~1%) between the theoretical and observed values for the first decomposition step could be a result of a small number of formamide vacancies formed during either the synthesis or drying process. The observed weight losses for the second and third steps are in good agreement with the calculated values.

elements.content: The six members of the LnFMD series show similar decomposition behavior ( Figure S7). All of the compounds show two well defined weight losses and broad third weight loss. Compared to the analogous members of the LnFA series, the LnFMD members are thermally more stable. The data for 10Sm are chosen as a representative example and are shown in Figure in comparison with 2Sm. Compound 10Sm begins to decompose at 473 K; the first weight loss of 24.45% is close to the calculated value of 23.85% based on the formation of Sm­(HCOO)3 by loss of [CH­(NH2)2]·[HCOO]. The second and third steps corresponding to the framework decomposition are identical to the decomposition behavior of 2Sm. The calculated weight loss corresponding to the decomposition of Sm­(HCOO)3 to Sm2O3 (29.40%) agrees with the observed value of 29.38%.

LnFMD

The six members of the LnFMD series show similar decomposition behavior ( Figure S7). All of the compounds show two well defined weight losses and broad third weight loss. Compared to the analogous members of the LnFA series, the LnFMD members are thermally more stable. The data for 10Sm are chosen as a representative example and are shown in Figure  in comparison with 2Sm. Compound 10Sm begins to decompose at 473 K; the first weight loss of 24.45% is close to the calculated value of 23.85% based on the formation of Sm(HCOO)3 by loss of [CH(NH2)2]⋅[HCOO]. The second and third steps corresponding to the framework decomposition are identical to the decomposition behavior of 2Sm. The calculated weight loss corresponding to the decomposition of Sm(HCOO)3 to Sm2O3 (29.40%) agrees with the observed value of 29.38%.

elements.content: All of the other LnFMD compounds decompose in a way similar to 10Sm with initial weight losses observed in the temperature range of 498–548 K. The theoretical weight losses are compared with the observed values and summarized in Table . The observed values are in good agreement with the theoretical values.

The theoretical weight losses are compared with the observed values and summarized in Table . The observed values are in good agreement with the theoretical values.

elements.content: The decomposition behavior of 7Tm, 8Yb, and 9Lu are influenced by the particle size. The behavior of 7Tm is shown as a representative example in Figure S8. The thermal analysis data for as-synthesized rhombohedral shaped crystals with sizes 0.5–1 mm showed initially two (at least) separate processes on the way to Ln­(HCOO)3 in contrast to the single step observed for small particles. Analysis of the powder X-ray diffraction patterns of the residues at different temperatures indicate that the thermal decomposition of LnFA to Ln­(HCOO)3 occurs via solid state transformation of LnFA to LnFMD (see Figure S8). The reaction kinetics of the decomposition are related to the crystal size. The slower decomposition of larger crystals allows sufficient time for the transformation of LnFA to LnFMD to occur.
elements.clean_text:
Effect of Particle Size on LnFA Decomposition

The decomposition behavior of 7Tm, 8Yb, and 9Lu are influenced by the particle size. The behavior of 7Tm is shown as a representative example in  Figure S8. The thermal analysis data for as-synthesized rhombohedral shaped crystals with sizes 0.5-1 mm showed initially two (at least) separate processes on the way to Ln(HCOO)3 in contrast to the single step observed for small particles. Analysis of the powder X-ray diffraction patterns of the residues at different temperatures indicate that the thermal decomposition of LnFA to Ln(HCOO)3 occurs via solid state transformation of LnFA to LnFMD (see  Figure S8). The reaction kinetics of the decomposition are related to the crystal size. The slower decomposition of larger crystals allows sufficient time for the transformation of LnFA to LnFMD to occur.

elements.content: Based on the results with rare earth oxides, the direct reaction of formamide and premixed phosphor was investigated. The particle size of the starting trichromatic phosphor was determined by SEM to be in the range of 4–10 μm (Figure a). The final products from the reactions were analyzed using SEM (Figure b). The final crystalline product was confirmed to be [CH­(NH2)2]­[Ln­(HCOO)4] by single crystal and powder X-ray diffraction measurements. The presence of Eu3+ in the crystal phase was confirmed from the four emission bands at 592, 618, 649, and 699 nm upon the excitation at 393 nm, and the presence of Tb3+ was confirmed from the two emission bands at 487 and 542 nm upon the excitation at 370 nm (Figure ). EDX measurements confirmed the presence of yttrium in the crystal phase.
elements.clean_text:
Recovery of Rare Earths as Formate Frameworks from Premixed Phosphor Materials

Based on the results with rare earth oxides, the direct reaction of formamide and premixed phosphor was investigated. The particle size of the starting trichromatic phosphor was determined by SEM to be in the range of 4-10 μm (Figure a). The final products from the reactions were analyzed using SEM (Figure b). The final crystalline product was confirmed to be [CH(NH2)2][Ln(HCOO)4] by single crystal and powder X-ray diffraction measurements. The presence of Eu3+ in the crystal phase was confirmed from the four emission bands at 592, 618, 649, and 699 nm upon the excitation at 393 nm, and the presence of Tb3+ was confirmed from the two emission bands at 487 and 542 nm upon the excitation at 370 nm (Figure ). EDX measurements confirmed the presence of yttrium in the crystal phase.

elements.content: The trichromatic phosphor is a model system for industrially used “real” phosphors, thus suggesting that reaction with formamide/water can be an acid free, environmentally friendly process to recover rare earth metals. Formamide can be catalytically hydrolyzed after use to ammonium formate for safe disposal or further use.
elements.clean_text: The trichromatic phosphor is a model system for industrially used "real" phosphors, thus suggesting that reaction with formamide/water can be an acid free, environmentally friendly process to recover rare earth metals. Formamide can be catalytically hydrolyzed after use to ammonium formate for safe disposal or further use.

elements.content: Hydrated rare earth nitrates react directly with formamide under mild conditions (≤100 °C) to form three distinct metal formates: Ln­(HCOO)3, Ln­(HCOO)3·(HCONH2)2, and [CH­(NH2)2] [Ln­(HCOO)4]. The formate ions are generated in situ by the reaction of the coordinated water molecules with formamide. The synthesis conditions were established for the formation of each structure type and were found to depend on the ion size of the rare earth and the reaction temperature and time. For the midsize rare earths, Ln­(HCOO)3·(HCONH2) converts to [CH­(NH2)2]­[Ln­(HCOO)4] at temperatures higher than 70 °C and for the small-size rare earths this conversion was observed to occur at temperatures higher than 50 °C as a function of time. For Tm, Yb, and Lu, the conversion is observed during the thermal decomposition of large crystals.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Hydrated rare earth nitrates react directly with formamide under mild conditions (≤100 °C) to form three distinct metal formates: Ln(HCOO)3, Ln(HCOO)3⋅(HCONH2)2, and [CH(NH2)2] [Ln(HCOO)4]. The formate ions are generated in situ by the reaction of the coordinated water molecules with formamide. The synthesis conditions were established for the formation of each structure type and were found to depend on the ion size of the rare earth and the reaction temperature and time. For the midsize rare earths, Ln(HCOO)3⋅(HCONH2) converts to [CH(NH2)2][Ln(HCOO)4] at temperatures higher than 70 °C and for the small-size rare earths this conversion was observed to occur at temperatures higher than 50 °C as a function of time. For Tm, Yb, and Lu, the conversion is observed during the thermal decomposition of large crystals.

elements.content: Replacing the nitrates with rare earth oxides as starting materials gave the same final results. In order to obtain reasonable reaction time (3–5 days), addition of small amounts of water was necessary to hydrolyze some formamide molecules to formate ions. The amount of water added must be controlled to prevent dissolution of the products and to avoid the formation of ammonium formate as a byproduct.
elements.clean_text: Replacing the nitrates with rare earth oxides as starting materials gave the same final results. In order to obtain reasonable reaction time (3-5 days), addition of small amounts of water was necessary to hydrolyze some formamide molecules to formate ions. The amount of water added must be controlled to prevent dissolution of the products and to avoid the formation of ammonium formate as a byproduct.

elements.content: Rare earth formates and their derivatives can be crystallized and recovered from the reactions of rare earth oxides with formamide containing small amounts of water. The results for the trichromatic phosphor model system indicate that other oxide materials containing rare earths such as fluorescent light bulb phosphors and CRT phosphors (after calcination) could be used in formamide/water recovery of rare earth elements from end-of-use products. A study of more complex oxides and mixtures is ongoing.
elements.clean_text: Rare earth formates and their derivatives can be crystallized and recovered from the reactions of rare earth oxides with formamide containing small amounts of water. The results for the trichromatic phosphor model system indicate that other oxide materials containing rare earths such as fluorescent light bulb phosphors and CRT phosphors (after calcination) could be used in formamide/water recovery of rare earth elements from end-of-use products. A study of more complex oxides and mixtures is ongoing.

cln_elements.content:
Compounds 10Sm–13Lu were synthesized by using a similar solvothermal synthesis procedure at 100 °C. However, the compounds with small rare earth ions, 12Tm, and 13Lu, crystallized even at 70 °C. A 0.5 mmol amount of hydrated rare earth­(III) nitrate was transferred to a 22 mL glass vial and mixed with 5 mL of formamide. Vials were sealed and heated at 100 °C for 72 h, followed by cooling to room temperature in ambient atmosphere. The final products were prismatic rod shaped crystals. The products were filtered, washed with ethanol, and dried in a vacuum oven. We noted also that reaction at 70 °C for longer reaction periods (>7 days) resulted in the transformation of Ln­(HCOO)3·(HCONH2)2 crystals to [CH­(NH2)2]­[Ln­(HCOO)4] crystals.

Pure phases of 11Ho, 12Tm, and 13Lu (except for 10Sm) were synthesized starting with rare earth oxides following a similar procedure: 0.125 mmol of rare earth­(III) oxide was transferred to a 22 mL glass vial and mixed with 10 mL of formamide and 0.25 mL of H2O. Vials were sealed and heated under autogenous pressure at 100 °C for 72 h. Vials were cooled to room temperature at ambient atmosphere, and the products were filtered, washed with ethanol, and dried in a vacuum oven.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [CH(NH2)2][Ln(HCOO)4] (Ln = 10Sm, 11Ho, 12Tm, and 13Lu)

Compounds 10Sm-13Lu were synthesized by using a similar solvothermal synthesis procedure at 100 °C. However, the compounds with small rare earth ions, 12Tm, and 13Lu, crystallized even at 70 °C. A 0.5 mmol amount of hydrated rare earth(III) nitrate was transferred to a 22 mL glass vial and mixed with 5 mL of formamide. Vials were sealed and heated at 100 °C for 72 h, followed by cooling to room temperature in ambient atmosphere. The final products were prismatic rod shaped crystals. The products were filtered, washed with ethanol, and dried in a vacuum oven. We noted also that reaction at 70 °C for longer reaction periods (>7 days) resulted in the transformation of Ln(HCOO)3⋅(HCONH2)2 crystals to [CH(NH2)2][Ln(HCOO)4] crystals.

Pure phases of 11Ho, 12Tm, and 13Lu (except for 10Sm) were synthesized starting with rare earth oxides following a similar procedure: 0.125 mmol of rare earth(III) oxide was transferred to a 22 mL glass vial and mixed with 10 mL of formamide and 0.25 mL of H2O. Vials were sealed and heated under autogenous pressure at 100 °C for 72 h. Vials were cooled to room temperature at ambient atmosphere, and the products were filtered, washed with ethanol, and dried in a vacuum oven.

cln_elements.content:
Three weight losses were observed for LnFA (1Y, 2Sm, 3Eu, 4Gd, 5Tb, 6Ho, 7Tm, 8Yb, and 9Lu). The results for ground samples (vide infra) are summarized in Table and in Figure S6. The data for 2Sm are shown in Figure as an example. The samarium compound loses weight (23.16%) below ∼400 K. The powder X-ray diffraction pattern of the residue after the first weight loss shows the formation of Sm­(HCOO)3, indicating loss of the coordinated formamide molecules. The weight loss corresponds to the loss of two molecules of formamide (24.10%). The anhydrous metal formate then decomposes at ∼614 K; an additional small weight loss occurs in the temperature range of 773–823 K. Previous studies of thermal decomposition of anhydrous rare earth formates have shown that decomposition leads to the (partial) formation of rare earth oxycarbonates Ln2O2·CO3 which then decompose at higher temperature. The calculated weight loss for the decomposition of Sm­(HCOO)3 completely to Sm2O 3 is 29.72%, in agreement with the observed total weight loss of 29.18% for the final two decomposition steps.

LnFMD

The six members of the LnFMD series show similar decomposition behavior ( Figure S7). All of the compounds show two well defined weight losses and broad third weight loss. Compared to the analogous members of the LnFA series, the LnFMD members are thermally more stable. The data for 10Sm are chosen as a representative example and are shown in Figure in comparison with 2Sm. Compound 10Sm begins to decompose at 473 K; the first weight loss of 24.45% is close to the calculated value of 23.85% based on the formation of Sm­(HCOO)3 by loss of [CH­(NH2)2]·[HCOO]. The second and third steps corresponding to the framework decomposition are identical to the decomposition behavior of 2Sm. The calculated weight loss corresponding to the decomposition of Sm­(HCOO)3 to Sm2O3 (29.40%) agrees with the observed value of 29.38%.
cln_elements.clean_text:
LnFA

Three weight losses were observed for LnFA (1Y, 2Sm, 3Eu, 4Gd, 5Tb, 6Ho, 7Tm, 8Yb, and 9Lu). The results for ground samples (vide infra) are summarized in Table  and in  Figure S6. The data for 2Sm are shown in Figure  as an example. The samarium compound loses weight (23.16%) below ~400 K. The powder X-ray diffraction pattern of the residue after the first weight loss shows the formation of Sm(HCOO)3, indicating loss of the coordinated formamide molecules. The weight loss corresponds to the loss of two molecules of formamide (24.10%). The anhydrous metal formate then decomposes at ~614 K; an additional small weight loss occurs in the temperature range of 773-823 K. Previous studies of thermal decomposition of anhydrous rare earth formates have shown that decomposition leads to the (partial) formation of rare earth oxycarbonates Ln2O2⋅CO3 which then decompose at higher temperature. The calculated weight loss for the decomposition of Sm(HCOO)3 completely to Sm2O 3 is 29.72%, in agreement with the observed total weight loss of 29.18% for the final two decomposition steps.

LnFMD

The six members of the LnFMD series show similar decomposition behavior ( Figure S7). All of the compounds show two well defined weight losses and broad third weight loss. Compared to the analogous members of the LnFA series, the LnFMD members are thermally more stable. The data for 10Sm are chosen as a representative example and are shown in Figure  in comparison with 2Sm. Compound 10Sm begins to decompose at 473 K; the first weight loss of 24.45% is close to the calculated value of 23.85% based on the formation of Sm(HCOO)3 by loss of [CH(NH2)2]⋅[HCOO]. The second and third steps corresponding to the framework decomposition are identical to the decomposition behavior of 2Sm. The calculated weight loss corresponding to the decomposition of Sm(HCOO)3 to Sm2O3 (29.40%) agrees with the observed value of 29.38%.
